prior_status: There were seven prior general protective servicesreferrals beginning in 2013 that involved allegations of substance use by the parents.
narrative: 21. A 2-year-old female child nearly died on February 5, 2017, as a result of seriousphysical neglect. Fayette County Children and Youth Services (FCCYS) indicated thereport on April 5, 2017, naming the mother as the perpetrator. On the date of incident,the child reportedly ingested Subutex. The mother observed her prescription bottle hadbeen opened and the child had a pill in her mouth. The medication was stored on theback of the kitchen sink in close proximity to the child’s candy jar, which she hadaccess to using a kitchen chair. It was unclear at the time how much of the Subutex thechild had ingested. The mother transported the child to the hospital due to the childappearing drowsy. The physicians gave the child a small amount of Narcan to stimulateher and she was transferred to a children’s hospital where she was found to be incritical condition. FCCYS assessed the safety of the four siblings. The mother voluntarilyplaced the four siblings with the maternal grandmother. When the child was releasedfrom the hospital on February 7, 2017, she was voluntarily placed with her siblings. Theplan remained in effect until the conclusion of the investigation and a dependencyhearing was held. The hearing was held on April 21, 2017, granting dependency of thechildren with their return to their mother’s care. The case remains open with FCCYS. Atthis time law enforcement has an ongoing investigation. The mother was referred for asubstance use assessment and intensive in-home services were initiated. FCCYS hadprior involvement with the family. There were seven prior general protective servicesreferrals beginning in 2013 that involved allegations of substance use by the parents.Three of these reports were screened out, three were assessed and closed at the intake level, and one was accepted for services from September 2015 to March 2016.Forest County

prior_status: LCOYFS had prior involvement with this family, including six reports from 2005 to 2016.
narrative: 24. A 7-month-old male child nearly died on February 26, 2017, as a result of seriousphysical neglect. Lackawanna County Office of Youth and Family Services (LCOYFS)indicated the case on April 5, 2017, naming the child’s parents as the perpetrators. The2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 13child was admitted to a local hospital on February 26, 2017, and then transferred to aspecialized hospital for further evaluation. Upon admission, the child was found to beseverely malnourished and suffering from severe metabolic derangements. In addition,there were multiple abrasions on his face, arm and leg, and raw/denuded skin in hisgenital region. Medical records indicated that the child had only two doctorappointments since his discharge from the hospital after birth. At the time of theincident there was a 2-year-old male sibling residing in the home. Due to the conditionof the victim child, LCOYFS obtained custody of both children. The child’s sibling wasplaced in the kinship home of the paternal grandfather on February 27, 2017, and thechild was discharged from a pediatric rehabilitation facility to the kinship home on May 10, 2017. The family was opened for services to assist with parenting, residentialstability, employment, medical oversight, and behavioral health and substance usetreatment. The victim child currently receives occupational therapy, physical therapy,and therapy for possible speech delays. Both parents were charged with endangering thewelfare of a child and recklessly endangering another person. The father was arrested onMarch 25, 2017, and released on his own recognizance. The mother was arrested onMarch 24, 2017, and remained incarcerated until she was able to make bail. Thefather’s bail restrictions require him to have no contact with his children. The mother isable to participate in supervised visitation. LCOYFS had prior involvement with this family, including six reports from 2005 to 2016. In 2005, the family was referred due toconcerns regarding the parents' ability to provide care for a child who was born withbirth defects and declared “brain dead” shortly after birth. The sibling was placed in amedical group home and the child’s father obtained custody of him. In 2008, a referralwas received regarding substance use by the parents. The case was closed at intakeafter ensuring protective capacities. In 2008, the mother was indicated for abuse due toa sibling suffering a bone fracture. The sibling was placed with the paternalgrandparents. In November 2015, a referral was received regarding a sibling being bornexhibiting withdrawal symptoms. The mother had been prescribed Subutex, and thecase was closed at intake. A referral was received in 2015 regarding the sibling residingwith the paternal grandparents displaying inappropriate sexual behaviors. Thegrandparents were able to provide appropriate safety and supervision of the sibling, andthe case was closed at intake. In August 2016, a referral was received when the victimchild was born with withdrawal symptoms due to the mother’s prescribed use ofSubutex. The child remained in the hospital for a month and was then discharged to theparents as no safety concerns were identified and the physicians had no concernsregarding the child. The case was closed at intake.Lancaster County

prior_status: The family was not known to the agency prior to thisincident.
narrative: 25. A 2-week-old male nearly died on March 29, 2017, as a result of a physical abuse.Lancaster County Children and Youth Services indicated the case on May 26, 2017,naming the child’s father as the perpetrator. On March 28, 2017, the father reportedchanging his son’s diaper. While holding his leg down, he heard a pop. The child wasseen at a nearby hospital and was admitted and treated for a broken femur. A doctorcertified the child to be in serious or critical condition. According to medical staff, abroken femur can only occur when extreme force is applied. The father stated that hemay have applied too much force while holding down the child’s leg. There are no otherchildren residing in the home. The family was accepted and referred for services. prior_status: LCOCYS had had prior involvement with this family.
narrative: 26. A 10-year-old female child nearly died on February 21, 2017, as a result of seriousphysical neglect. Lehigh County Office of Children and Youth Services (LCOCYS)indicated the case on April 21, 2017, naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator. OnFebruary 19, 2017, the child was taken to the hospital by her father. She was found tohave symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and hyperglycemia. The child was also diagnosedwith sleep apnea/tonsillar hypertrophy, vitamin D deficiency, premature adrenarche,hypertrophic and atrophic condition of the skin. During this hospitalization, the motherprovided inconsistent information to the medical staff and was insistent that the childshould be handling her own diabetic regimen. The child reported to hospital staff thatshe usually misses one dose of insulin per week; however, her laboratory valuesindicated she was missing doses more frequently. It was found that the child had missedseventeen appointments for endocrinology and intensive management since July 2015,missed ten pediatric clinic appointments since November 2015, and had been admittedto the intensive care unit six times in less than a year. The child reported that sheprimarily resided with her mother and had visits with her father. During theinvestigation, the mother admitted she had not supervised the child’s administration ofinsulin. She also admitted that the child figured out her own carbohydrate intake andmeasure of insulin. The mother stated she did not check the child’s blood sugar atbedtime as recommended medically. The father admitted that he did not have a plan ofcare for the child during his overnight work schedule and he did not make himselfavailable to the education provided by the hospital regarding diabetic care for hisdaughter. The child was adjudicated dependent and discharged to her godmother’s home on February 25, 2017. The godmother has experience in diabetic care. The child’sthree siblings remained with the mother as there were no safety concerns regarding theircare. No charges have been filed. LCOCYS had had prior involvement with this family.One general protective services (GPS) referral in December 2013 and one GPS in October2014 were received for substance use, domestic violence, and lack of medical insurance.The family was opened for ongoing services from October 2014 through May 2015 forissues related to the child’s diabetes. From September 2015 to January 2017, four GPSreferrals were received for domestic violence issues and concerns of substandardhousing. The family was referred to services between November 2016 and January 2017with focus on housing assistance.Luzerne County

prior_status: The family has a history of involvement with LCCYS.
narrative: 27. A 5-year-old female child nearly died on April 17, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Luzerne County Children and Youth Services (LCCYS) indicated the case on May15, 2017, naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator for failing to provide the childwith proper medical care. The child had been seen by her primary care physician onApril 14, 2017, when the mother was instructed to take the child to the emergency roomfor treatment. The mother waited until three days later to take the child to the localhospital due to flu-like symptoms and the child being “out of it.” The child wastransferred to a pediatric specialty hospital for further treatment of diabetic ketoacidosis(DKA). The mother denied noncompliance with the child’s diabetes management statingthat the child was sick and not keeping anything down, including insulin. The twotreating physicians stated that the spike in the child’s blood sugar level occurredbecause the mother was not giving the child the proper amounts of insulin. The childentered foster care upon discharge from the hospital. The child’s 3-year-old sibling2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 15remains in the home as there are no concerns for his safety in the care of his mother.LCCYS continues to provide ongoing support and services to the family includingvisitation, substance use treatment, parenting and diabetes education. The child attendsa pediatric day health center. Mother’s visitation with the child occurs at the healthcenter where she receives diabetes education for the care of her daughter. The victim childwas certified to be in critical condition and transferred to a regional hospital. The motherreported that the victim child was dropped on the floor by his 6-year-old sibling thatmorning and slept through the day while the family was on a shopping trip for seven toeight hours. The physician confirmed that the victim child’s injuries could not have beensustained as reported by the perpetrator. The mother later admitted to striking the child.The child has three siblings that were also residing in the home. The siblings weremedically evaluated, and it was determined that they had no prior or current injuries.Due to the severity of the victim child’s injuries, all four children were placed in the custody of MCCYS via emergency shelter care order on April 13, 2017. The siblings are placed together in a differentfoster home and are receiving case management services. The oldest sibling is beingevaluated for behavioral health services. The agency has made referrals through theInterstate Office for the children to be placed with either the maternal or paternalgrandparents. Two siblings were placed in the custody of the agency from April 2015to February 2016 due to parental drug use and criminal drug activity in the home. Themother was charged with child endangerment. The mother was residing in another stateat the time, and the children were returned home to the mother through the Interstate Office after the mother’s child endangerment charges were dismissed in February 2016.The father of the children was arrested and charged with drug-related criminal offensesand was incarcerated. In March 2016, MCCYS learned that the family moved back toMonroe County. In September 2016, the case was closed after the parents demonstrateda substantial period of sobriety and were able to maintain employment and housing.Perry County

narrative: 30. A 5-month-old male child nearly died on February 18, 2017, as a result of physicalabuse. prior_status: The family was known to PDHS prior to this incident.
narrative: 33. A 4-year-old male child nearly died on May 3, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case on June 29,2017, naming the child’s mother and paramour as the perpetrators. On May 3, 2017,the child was taken to the babysitter’s house at 6:00 AM. Approximately 15 minuteslater the babysitter observed the child to wobble and fall to the ground and begin to have a seizure. The babysitter contacted 9-1-1. The child was taken to a local hospital wherea computed axial tomography (CAT) scan revealed a skull fracture on the right side ofhis head including a hematoma and a midline shift. A medical evaluation revealed thechild also suffered a rib fracture and multiple bruises. The child was then transferred toa specialized pediatric hospital. The mother and her paramour, who were responsible forthe care and well-being of the child, could not give a reliable explanation as to how thechild sustained the injuries. The mother reported the child had hurt his head on April 4,2017, and was taken to a pediatric hospital; however, a CAT scan was performed, andno fracture was reported. The child was unable to reliably articulate details as to howthe injuries occurred. The half-sibling was placed in foster care to ensure her safety. Thevictim child transitioned to a rehabilitation center and then to a medical foster home in July 2017. A criminal investigation is ongoing, and charges have not been filed. Themother and paramour were referred to parenting services as well as case managementservices. Both the mother and her paramour are not to visit the child until he ismedically cleared. The mother and her paramour are participating in weekly supervisedvisits with the child’s half-sibling. The family was known to PDHS prior to this incident.The mother was known as a child. The father, mother and paramour were investigatedin the 2011 death of a 6-month-old child of the mother and father. The cause of deathwas determined to be accidental.

prior_status: The PDHS had prior involvement with this family since 2011.
narrative: 34. A 4-year-old male child nearly died on February 14, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case on April 4, 2017,naming the maternal uncle as the perpetrator. The child resided in the home of hisfather. The father reported that either on February 13 or 14, 2017, he took the child tothe maternal uncle’s home for child care while he went to work. The father stated thathe received a telephone call from the maternal uncle on February 14, 2017, reportingthat the child had a little burn due to bath water being hot, but the father did not needto rush to get the child and the child did not need to go to the hospital. When the fatherreturned on February 17, 2017, he saw the child had socks on his hands covering theburns. The father called emergency services. The child was taken to a children’s hospitaland then transferred to a specialized hospital. The father stated he had not known theburns were severe. The maternal uncle stated that he left the child in the tub notknowing that the water was extremely hot. Medical reports indicate that the childsustained second degree burns covering 24 percent of his body. There were no splashpatterns to the burns, which indicated that someone held the child down in the water.On March 17, 2017, the child’s father, his maternal uncle, and the paramour of thematernal uncle were arrested and charged with aggravated assault, endangering thewelfare of a child, simple assault, and recklessly endangering another person. On April21, 2017, the child’s father was released on bail. The maternal uncle and the paramourof the maternal uncle remain incarcerated. They were scheduled for a pre-trial hearing2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 19 in August 2017. The victim child was discharged from the rehabilitation center on April24, 2017, and placed into medical kinship care. The child has three siblings that are also in kinship care. The PDHS had prior involvement with this family since 2011. Mostrecently, a child protective services (CPS) report was received in October 2016, however,no safety threats were identified, and the child was determined to be safe. The case was closed in November 2016. In January 2017, a CPS report alleged that the father had cutthe victim child on his face with scissors. It was alleged that the father was using drugs,had a criminal history, and had taken the victim child away from the mother. A custodyhearing concerning the victim child was scheduled for April 2017 where it wasdetermined that there were no safety threats in the home of the victim child’s mother. Atthe time of the incident PDHS had been attempting to locate the victim child and hisfather since January 2017 to no avail until the report of the child’s hospitalization wasreceived.Schuylkill County

prior_status: SCCYS has had prior involvement with this family.
narrative: 36. A 22-month-old female child nearly died on April 9, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Schuylkill County Children and Youth Services (SCCCYS) indicated the case onMay 9, 2017, naming the child’s mother, father, and caregiver as the perpetrators. OnApril 9, 2017, the child was found chewing a methamphetamine bag in the home wherethe family resided. The child was monitored by the mother and the father for some time until she started to display seizure-like behavior, resulting in the parents calling 9-1-1.The child was flown via air-ambulance to a regional hospital and was listed in criticalcondition with an unknown prognosis. The child tested positive for methamphetamine,amphetamine and methylenedioxy-methamphetamine (MDMA). When she arrived at thehospital she was in tachycardia, with a very high heart rate. The child was sedated tocontrol her heart rate and was on a ventilator to control her breathing. The child waslisted in critical condition. The parents reportedly appeared to be under the influence atthe time of the incident. At the time of the incident the caregiver was not present in thehome. There was a court ordered safety plan in place for the family stating that thecaregiver would not allow any unsupervised contact between the father and the child,and would not allow the father to reside in the home. During the investigation, it wasfound that the father was residing in the home. Both parents denied usingmethamphetamine, but later the mother did admit she had used on April 8 to April 9, 2017. Both parents stated they had no knowledge as to how the child accessed thedrugs. The caregiver reported that prior to leaving the home on the date of the incident,she saw the parents and the child sleeping on the first floor of the home. The parentswere charged with aggravated assault, simple assault, possession of drugs, endangeringthe welfare of a child and reckless endangerment, and were incarcerated. The child’smother and caregiver also failed to follow through with a court-ordered safety plan byallowing the father in the home and unsupervised access to the victim child. The motherwas incarcerated and released in May 2017 and immediately entered a psychiatricfacility. The child was placed in foster care upon her discharge from the hospital. AnInterstate Compact referral has been made for the maternal grandfather to become akinship home for the victim child. SCCYS has had prior involvement with this family. InJuly 2013, a referral was made regarding concerns of the parent’s drug use, unstablehousing, and the basic needs of the sibling not being met. The case was open fromSeptember 2013 until July 2014 when it was closed after custody of the sibling wastransferred to the maternal grandfather. The second referral was received on June 12,2015, when the victim child was born due to concerns of domestic violence and theparents’ lack of coping skills. The case was opened for services on August 10, 2015, andcontinued to be open at the time of the incident. The family was receiving parenting,drug and alcohol, and mental health counseling services, however, participation andcompliance was sporadic. The victim child’s basic and medical needs were being met. Asafety plan was in place indicating the father would reside outside the home and allcontact with the child would be supervised.York County

prior_status: The family was not known to YCCYF prior to this near fatality.
narrative: 37. A 2-month-old male child nearly died on March 31, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.On May 16, 2017, York County Children, Youth and Families (YCCYF) indicated thefather as the perpetrator. On March 31, 2017, the father stated he heard the child2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 21crying around 4:00 AM and called the paternal grandparents and the child’s mother forassistance. The paternal grandfather went to the home to help, but the child continuedto cry. The child’s mother arrived home from work at about 6:00 AM and the mother andfather took the child to the local hospital. A computerized axial tomography (CAT) scandetermined the child had a brain bleed and severe bruising to the left side of his head.On May 30, 2017, the child was transferred to a medical center. Neither parent couldprovide an explanation for the injuries. On April 3, 2017, the child was released from themedical center and YCCYF placed him with a family friend on a safety plan. A few dayslater the family friend stated she was not comfortable supervising contact between thechild and father. The child was then placed in the care of his paternal grandparents.During the investigation, the father had stated he dropped the child, however, a hospitalphysician stated the injuries were not consistent with a fall. A few weeks later the fatherinformed law enforcement that he had slapped the child in the face because the childwould not stop crying. He also admitted to being intoxicated the night of the incident.The father was charged with aggravated assault and endangering the welfare of a child.He is currently incarcerated and awaiting his hearing. Neither parent has any otherchildren. The victim child remains in the care of his paternal grandparents who havebeen approved as formal kinship caregivers. The child has been assessed and has beenfound to be on track developmentally, however, due to his injuries he may be monitoredto ensure that no concerns develop. The mother is participating in a parenting program.The goal is for the victim child to return to his mother’s care and custody. He hassupervised visitation with his mother several times per week. While incarcerated, thefather is to be participating in parenting, substance use treatment, and angermanagement courses. The family was not known to YCCYF prior to this near fatality.

prior_status: Lehigh County Office of Children and Youth Services had prior involvement with the victimchild’s family.
narrative: 9. A 3-month-old female child died on April 1, 2016, as a result of serious physical neglect.Department of Human Services’ Office of Children, Youth, and Families Northeast RegionalOffice (NERO) indicated the case on July 6, 2017, naming the owner of a daycare as theperpetrator. On April 1, 2016, the victim child was found to be unresponsive whenemergency medical services personnel responded to a licensed daycare in NorthamptonCounty. The daycare was in the owner’s home. The victim child was transported to a localhospital where she was pronounced dead. It was subsequently determined that the victimchild was left unsupervised for an extended period of time in a crib in the bedroom area ofthe perpetrator’s home which was also an unlicensed space. On May 18, 2016, NERO submitted a status of pending criminal court. Criminal charges were filed in April 2017.The perpetrator was charged with reckless endangerment and endangering the welfare of achild. On September 15, 2017, the perpetrator entered a guilty plea on one count ofendangering the welfare of a child and one count of reckless endangerment. As a result ofthe plea agreement, the perpetrator was sentenced to seven years of probation and a$5,000 fine. As a result of the criminal conviction, the status was changed to founded.Lehigh County Office of Children and Youth Services had prior involvement with the victimchild’s family. In December 2015, a general protective services referral was received due tothe mother’s possible substance use and the victim child’s exposure at the time of delivery.This was closed at the intake level with no recommended services following a home visitand consultation with the family’s medical provider. The perpetrator had no known priorinvolvement with the child welfare system.

prior_status: NCCYFD had prior involvement with the family.
narrative: 10. An 11-month-old female child died on July 28, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Northampton County Children, Youth and Families Division (NCCYFD) indicatedthe case on August 24, 2017, naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator. On July 27,2017, the mother reportedly placed the victim child and the child’s 23-month-old siblingtogether in the bathtub. The mother had been drinking alcohol and taking othermedication and left the bathroom for about five minutes to text her paramour. When thechild’s sibling called her name, she entered the bathroom and found the child face down inthe water and unresponsive. The mother took the child out of the bathtub and made three phone calls prior to dialing 9-1-1. The child was transported to the hospital and was2017 3rd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesJuly 1 to September 30, 2017 5determined to be in critical condition. The child was then transferred to a trauma center.The cause of death was determined to be anoxic brain injury as a result of drowning. Thechild’s sibling was placed with relatives as part of a safety plan. The criminal investigationis pending the final toxicology report for the child. The family was accepted for services on August 24, 2017. In addition to reunification services, the mother will be provided withparenting, behavioral health, and substance use services. The sibling will be provided withcounseling services. The sibling was evaluated by medical professionals and furtherdevelopmental tests were recommended. NCCYFD had prior involvement with the family. Achild protective services referral was received in August 2015, with allegations of domesticviolence. The report was investigated and unfounded. The family was accepted for servicesincluding the implementation of safety plans, in-home services, and ensuring the childrenreceive appropriate medical care. The case was closed in May 2016, as concerns had beenresolved.Philadelphia County

prior_status: Thefamily was known to PDHS and open for services at the time of the incident.
narrative: 11. A 2-month-old male child died on June 2, 2017, as a result of serious physical neglect.Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case on July 11, 2017,naming both the mother and father as the perpetrators. The father reports that on May 27,2017, he fell down a few stairs while holding the child in his arms. He had the childcradled against his arm and did not believe the child hit his head; the child did not cry.The mother and father kept an eye on the child the rest of the night and next day. On May28, 2017, the child’s face was swollen, and he was running a fever above 105 degrees. Theparents did not seek medical care for the child at this time. On May 29, 2017, the childwas unresponsive and emergency medical services (EMS) were called. Cardiopulmonaryresuscitation was performed by EMS and the child was revived. The child was transportedto the hospital in critical condition, and observed to have a bruise above the left eye and acut to the left side of the lip. Tests revealed three linear fractures at the back of the headand bruising to the child’s eye, which were consistent with the father’s fall. The hospitalphysicians determined the child had suffered cardiac arrest due to inflicted trauma. OnJune 2, 2017, the child was removed from life support and was pronounced dead. Acriminal investigation is ongoing. This was the only child of the mother and father. Thefamily was known to PDHS and open for services at the time of the incident. In April 2017,a child protective services report was received alleging physical abuse. The child washospitalized for evaluation, and upon discharge, was placed in the care of a relative as asafety measure. The child was returned to the parents’ care in May 2017, with services inplace. The child protective services report was determined to be unfounded in June 2017,as the child’s injuries appeared to be consistent with a child carrier the parents hadutilized.

prior_status: PDHS had no prior involvement with thisfamily.
narrative: 14. A 2-year-old male child died on July 14, 2017, as a result of physical abuse. PhiladelphiaDepartment of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case on August 16, 2017, naming thechild’s father as the perpetrator. On July 14, 2017, the child was transported to a regionalchildren’s hospital via ambulance. The child was in the care of his father at the time of theincident. The father reported the child was in another room when he heard what soundedlike the child falling down steps. The father investigated and found the child at the bottomof carpeted steps. The child was moaning but non-responsive. He attempted to revive thechild by taking him in the shower and giving him juice. When the child did not respond, hecalled 9-1-1 and the operator instructed him on how to perform cardiopulmonaryresuscitation (CPR). The father performed CPR until the ambulance arrived. The child waspronounced dead shortly after arriving at the hospital. Physicians determined the child’sinjuries were not consistent with falling down steps and the child was deceased prior to the2017 3rd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesJuly 1 to September 30, 2017 7 call to 9-1-1. The child was noted to have multiple bruises in different stages of healing.The child’s death was ruled a homicide caused by blunt force trauma to the torso andother extremities. The child’s mother’s 17-year-old sister lived in the home, but was notpresent at the time of the incident. She was placed in a respite home for her safety duringthe investigation, and subsequently moved to the home of her paternal grandmother. Thefather was arrested and charged with murder and endangering the welfare of a child. He is currently incarcerated. A formal arraignment was scheduled to occur November 21, 2017.No services have been provided to the family. PDHS had no prior involvement with thisfamily.

prior_status: The family was not known to PDHS.
narrative: 15. A 3-month-old female child died on July 3, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case on July 26, 2017,naming the child’s mother and father as the perpetrators. On June 30, 2017, the child wasin the care of the father. He called 9-1-1 in the evening due to the child being in anunusually deep sleep. Emergency medical services (EMS) administered oxygen to the childand the child appeared to be stable. EMS reportedly informed the father to call againshould the child have a reoccurrence of symptoms. Later that night the father called 9-1-1again due to the child vomiting and then becoming unresponsive. Two neighborsadministered cardiopulmonary resuscitation until the ambulance arrived. The child wastaken to a pediatric hospital in an unresponsive state. The child was resuscitated andadmitted for continued care. A medical exam revealed the child to have several bruises onher head, right arm, and upper back, as well as a subdural hemorrhage, and an optic nerve hemorrhage. The child died on July 3, 2017. The mother stated that the child was upto date with her medical care and had no known medical conditions. The parents couldprovide no explanation as to the child’s injuries. An autopsy determined the child died fromblunt force trauma. On August 9, 2017, the father was arrested and charged with murder,involuntary manslaughter, and endangering the welfare of a child. He was incarcerated, and his next hearing is scheduled for January 10, 2018. There were no other children inthe home. The family was not known to PDHS.

prior_status: BCCYF had no prior involvement with this family.
narrative: 19. A 3-month-old male child nearly died on June 13, 2017, as a result of physical abuse. OnJuly 18, 2017, Bucks County Children and Youth Social Services (BCCYSS) named thebabysitter as the perpetrator. On June 12, 2017, the mother had left the child in the careof a babysitter. When the mother arrived home from work, she noticed the child was pale,moaning, cold, and his eyes were barely open. The babysitter, who had been employed forthree days, had not notified the mother that the child was ill. The babysitter informed themother that she had given the child Tylenol and that the child had been vomiting. Themother called the pediatrician who told her to take the child to the hospital. The victimchild was taken to a local hospital. A spinal tap revealed a brain bleed. The physicianstated that the child displayed signs of being shaken. The child was airlifted to a regionalchildren’s hospital where further tests indicated the child had a subdural hematoma and aretinal hemorrhage in the left eye. When interviewed, the babysitter stated that she wasbouncing the child and the child hit his head on the arm of the chair. The child has beenreturned to the care of his parents. He is scheduled for follow up treatment withspecialists, as well as physical and occupational therapy. This is the only child of theparents. BCCYF had no prior involvement with this family.Chester County

prior_status: Thefamily had no prior involvement with CCDCYF.
narrative: 20. A 5-month-old female child nearly died on June 12, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Chester County Department of Children, Youth and Families (CCDCYF) indicatedthe case on July 28, 2017, naming the child’s mother and father as the perpetrators. Themother and father reported the child had been ill for a few weeks. The family is Amish, andthe child was not immunized. The mother had taken the child to a pediatrician on June 5,2017, where the child was diagnosed with an upper respiratory infection and prescribedmedication. The mother did not follow through with the instructions from the pediatricianfor follow-up care or for administering the medication, and the child’s condition worsened.On June 9, 2017, the mother and father consulted with an elder in the Amish communitywho diagnosed the child with whooping cough and pneumonia. The elder instructed themother to use home remedies to treat the child’s condition. A follow-up visit with the elder was scheduled for July 12, 2017. When the child’s condition still did not improve over thenext few days, the mother and father arranged for the child to be transported to the hospital on June 12, 2017. The child presented with fever, coughing, difficulty breathing,and seizure activity. The child was transferred to a regional pediatric hospital, where thechild was put on a ventilator. The child remained hospitalized from June 12, 2017, until her discharge on July 7, 2017. The mother and father were given instructions foradministering the child’s medication and were trained in the process by hospital staff. Asafety plan was implemented by CCDCYF that required oversight of the child’s care byfamily members and neighbors in the Amish community. The family was provided withcase management services to assist with ensuring the child’s healthy development. The2017 3rd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesJuly 1 to September 30, 2017 11parents have no other children. At this time, no criminal charges have been filed. Thefamily had no prior involvement with CCDCYF.

prior_status: This family was known to LCCYS prior to the incident.
narrative: 24. A 10-month-old female child nearly died on July 14, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Lebanon County Children and Youth Services (LCCYS) indicated the case on August 24,2017, naming the child’s uncle and maternal grandmother as the perpetrators. The child had been informally placed in the custody of the maternal grandparents in March 2017.The child’s maternal uncle, who is under the age of 18, also lives in the home. On July 14,2017, the maternal grandmother called the victim child’s caseworker to inform her that she2017 3rd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesJuly 1 to September 30, 2017 13was taking the child to the emergency room due to the child having difficulty breathing.The child was transported to a local hospital by ambulance. The child’s blood sugar levelwas elevated, and significant physical injuries were noted. The child was transferred to apediatric specialty hospital in critical condition. She was found to have a moderate sizedleft pneumothorax, liver lacerations, spleen lacerations, a right adrenal hematoma, patchyareas of hypoattenuation in her right kidney (suspicious for solid organ injury), andmoderate volume complex hemorrhagic ascites. She was found to have three largesubdural brain hemorrhages, bilateral retinal hemorrhaging, bruises to the face and head,and an injury to the cervical area of the spine. All injuries were believed to be due to non-accidental trauma. During the investigation, the maternal grandmother noted that thevictim child had been lethargic for several days prior to being taken to the hospital. Thematernal grandmother had left the child in the care of the child’s uncle on the day of theincident. When interviewed, the uncle admitted to vigorously shaking and squeezing thechild to make her stop crying. The maternal grandmother was aware that the uncle hadanger issues but still allowed him to babysit the child daily. The child has been placed infoster care. The uncle was arrested and incarcerated in a detention center. The maternalgrandmother was arrested August 7, 2017, and charged with endangering the welfare of achild. This family was known to LCCYS prior to the incident. In December 2016, a childprotective services (CPS) report was received resulting in both of the victim child’s parentsbeing indicated for creating a reasonable likelihood of bodily injury. The case was acceptedfor services in February 2017 due to the mother’s instability and actions. Two separateCPS cases were reported in March 2017 with concerns for safety and lack of supervision.These cases were unfounded.Luzerne County

prior_status: The family had a history of involvement with LCCYS, as well as child welfareservices in New York.
narrative: 25. A 2-month-old male child nearly died on July 24, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Luzerne County Children and Youth Services (LCCYS) indicated the case on August 22,2017, naming the child’s father as the perpetrator. On July 24, 2017, the father and afamily member took the child to a local hospital with symptoms of being limp, listless, andunresponsive. The child was determined to have multiple injuries including acute andsubacute subdural hematoma, bilateral retinal hemorrhages, metaphysical fracture of theright humerus, and eleven bilateral rib fractures. On July 25, 2017, the child wastransferred to a regional medical center. While hospitalized, the child developed seizureactivity as a result of the trauma. The child was diagnosed with abusive head trauma. Thefather was the only adult caregiver in the home at the time of the incident. The victimchild’s 22-month-old sibling was in the home at the time of the incident; she was placed inemergency foster care. On July 31, 2017, the victim child was discharged from the hospitaland was placed with the emergency caregivers. The mother resides in the same home andhas supervised contact with the children. The father is restricted from all contact with thechildren. There have been no criminal charges filed, however, the criminal investigationcontinues. The family had a history of involvement with LCCYS, as well as child welfareservices in New York. There were two prior general protective services referrals received byLCCYS in February 2017 and June 2017 alleging the father’s unstable behavioral healthand parental substance use. In February, one referral was screened-out and the other wasclosed at the intake level. At the time of the near fatality, the June 2017 referral was activeand remains open. The mother has engaged in parenting education, a behavioral healthevaluation, as well as individual counseling. The father has not engaged in services.2017 3rd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesJuly 1 to September 30, 2017 14Mercer County

prior_status: The family had no prior involvement with MCCYS.
narrative: 26. A 1-year-old female child nearly died on August 3, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Mercer County Children and Youth Services (MCCYS) indicated the case on August 31,2017, naming the mother and the mother’s paramour as the perpetrators. On July 30,2017, the mother took the child to an urgent care center where the child was diagnosedwith hand, foot, and mouth disease. The child was taken to the pediatrician’s office onAugust 3, 2017, for follow up treatment. While there, medical staff observed a fresh bruiseon her forehead as well as older bruising over her body. The child was referred to a localhospital for a skeletal scan and other testing. On the evening on August 3, 2017, themother and her paramour took the child to a children’s hospital in Ohio with concerns thatthe child was not eating and vomiting. The child continued vomiting and began havingseizures while at the hospital. During the evaluation, the child was found to have a rightparietal skull fracture and subdural hematomas along the brain. She had a number ofbruises on her forehead, shoulders, and sacral area. There was reddened skin on herbuttocks, upper thigh, and left foot that were diagnosed as healing burns. The child wasadmitted and continued to have seizures. Further testing determined that the child hadtwo retinal hemorrhages in her left eye. She had a healing fracture of the left forearm. OnAugust 17, 2017, an external ventricular drain was inserted to drain blood from her head.The injuries to the child were determined not to be accidental. Law enforcement continuesto investigate. The child has been removed from the mother’s care and is now in the care ofher father. The mother is only permitted to have visitation while supervised by MCCYS oran assigned provider. The child’s two siblings were also removed from the care of theirmother. One is in the care of her biological father and the other now resides with hermaternal grandmother. During the investigation, the child’s mother and her paramourwere also indicated for abuse against the victim child’s sibling for interfering in the child’sbreathing. The family had no prior involvement with MCCYS.Montgomery County

Thevictim child has an older sibling who is in the custody of his biological father. The fatherwas arrested on July 6, 2017, and charged with aggravated assault, endangering thewelfare of children, simple assault, and reckless endangerment. He was released on bail on July 7, 2017, and scheduled for formal arraignment on October 31, 2017. The child will beassessed for developmental concerns and referred for early intervention if necessary. Themother and father will be referred for parenting capacity evaluations and behavioral healthevaluations, in addition to random drug screenings. This family was known to PDHS. The mother’s paramour becameconcerned and contacted the child’s mother, and his aunt and grandmother. The childbegan to lose consciousness with liquid coming from his mouth. prior_status: Thefamily has a history of involvement with LCCYS.

The mother was not home at the time of the incident.The child contacted emergency services requesting help. Police, fire, and ambulanceresponded. The child was pronounced dead on October 25, 2017, as aresult of carbon monoxide poisoning due to smoke inhalation. The half-sibling’sfather requested the local police department complete a child welfare check. When policeentered the home, the mother was found sleeping on the couch and water was heardrunning in the bathroom. narrative: 8. A 3-week-old male child nearly died on August 22, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Adams County Children and Youth indicated the case on October 20, 2017, namingthe mother and paternal aunt as the perpetrators. The child was incorrectly placed in abouncy chair intentionally because the child did not fit properly due to his small size. Themother and paternal aunt who were caring for the child left the child unsupervised forapproximately 20 minutes. Upon their return, the victim child was found on the floor with alump on the side of his head. Later that evening, the mother took the child to the emergencyroom. The child was determined to have sustained a skull fracture. The victim child’s siblingand paternal cousin were present in the home at the time of the incident. A safety plan wasenacted to ensure the mother and paternal aunt have no unsupervised contact with thechildren while the case was being investigated. The family was referred for intensive familysupport services, parenting education classes, and early intervention services. There havebeen no criminal charges filed. narrative: 10. A 10-month-old female child nearly died on October 24, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Allegheny County Office of Children, Youth and Families (ACOCYF) indicated thecase on November 29, 2017, naming the child’s mother and father as the perpetrators. OnOctober 24, 2017, the parents contacted emergency medical services due to the childhaving an altered mental status and irregular breathing. The child was transported to thelocal hospital via ambulance and admitted. The child tested positive for Suboxone. Themother stated that she is prescribed Suboxone. The child was also noted to have bacterialpneumonia. The treating physician determined that the Suboxone along with the bacterialpneumonia caused the child’s critical condition. There was one sibling present in the homeat the time of the incident. The victim child and her sibling were placed in a kinship carehome of a paternal family friend. On November 18, 2017, the parents were charged with2017 4th Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesOctober 1 to December 30, 2017 5aggravated assault, endangering welfare of children, and recklessly endangering anotherperson. The mother was incarcerated on November 21, 2017, and released on November formal arraignment on February 20, 2018. A no contact order was in place for the motherand father, however the mother’s was lifted. This family was known to ACOCYF prior to thisincident. Five prior referrals had been received between February 2014 and September 2016. There were three general protective service (GPS) referrals in 2014 and 2015regarding inadequate housing, parental substance use, and behavioral health concerns. Thefirst GPS referral was screened out as the family did not reside in the county at that time.The second and third GPS referrals resulted in services being offered but not provided. In2016, there were two child protective services (CPS) referrals. The family received in-homeservices from October 2016 to September 2017 as a result of a sibling’s ingestion ofbuprenorphine. The report was unfounded, but services were provided to assist withmonitoring safe storage of medication, housing assistance, parenting skills, and linking thefamily to community services. The second CPS referral occurred when the sibling wasinjured in an all-terrain vehicle accident. No services were offered, and the case is stillpending criminal court.

The physicians determined she had an enlargedheart, resulting in her being transferred via ambulance to the local pediatric hospital. Thechild was diagnosed with heart failure, low vitamin D levels, and rickets due to malnutrition.The child demonstrated significant developmental delays and was also behind in herimmunizations. The family reported that the child had received little medical care since herbirth and had not received immunizations by the parents’ choice. There are three siblingspresent in the home. Their safety was ensured. They remained in the home with theparents. ACOCYF opened the family to ensure that medical follow-up is occurring. Nocharges were filed, and law enforcement closed their case. The family had no priordocumented child welfare involvement.Beaver County

narrative: 12. narrative: 14. A 14-year-old female child nearly died on September 7, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Blair County Children, Youth, and Families (BCCYF) indicated the case onNovember 6, 2017, naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator. The mother observed thechild on the floor of her bedroom and told the child to get ready for school. The mother wentback to the child’s bedroom later and noted that the child was on the floor and covered inurine and vomit. The mother called for emergency medical services (EMS) an hour and ahalf later. EMS staff arrived at the home to find the child in an unresponsive state, still layingon the floor covered in urine. EMS transported the child to the local hospital and the childwas subsequently transferred to a pediatric hospital. The mother’s delay in seekingtreatment caused the child's condition to worsen, requiring the child to be intubated. Thechild’s symptoms indicated ingestion of a substance; however, toxicology reports werenegative. A search of the family home conducted by law enforcement did not yield anysubstances that the child may have ingested. BCCYF assessed that the child was safe inthe home of her mother and father, and the child was discharged on September 11, 2017, tothe care of her parents. The incident continues to be investigated by police. BCCYF did nothave any prior involvement with this family. There was a report in 2016 for the family whilethey were residing in West Virginia which involved suspected drug dealing; the father’s casewas dismissed, and the mother’s case is still pending. The family moved to ClearfieldCounty, and then relocated to Blair County. Clearfield County Children and Youth opened the family for services in March 2017. The case was closed when the child was determinedsafe and the family declined services.2017 4th Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesOctober 1 to December 30, 2017 7Bradford County

narrative: 15. A 1-month-old male child nearly died on September 7, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Bradford County Children and Youth Services (BCCYS) indicated the case onOctober 10, 2017, naming the biological mother and father as the perpetrators. The child had notgained weight in 42 days. There was one other sibling present at the time of the incident. Asafety assessment resulted in the sibling remaining in the care/custody of a relative. Thevictim child was placed in foster care upon discharge from the medical facility. The parentswere provided feeding instructions by the medical provider, as well as intensive supportservices. The victim child was returned to the care of the parents in November 2017 withongoing services. The criminal investigation was completed in October 2017 with nocharges being filed. This family had prior involvement with BCCYS for two children due tothe mother allowing a Megan’s Law sex offender access to her home after repeated requests to prohibit access. narrative: 16. A 2-month-old female child nearly died on September 14, 2017, as a result of physicalabuse. Dauphin County Social Services for Children and Youth indicated the case onNovember 13, 2017, naming the biological father as the perpetrator. The ribfractures were in various stages of healing. The mother was interviewed and reported thechild was fine before she left for work the day of the incident. The father was caring for thechild the day of the incident but denied causing the injuries. He reported the child was fussythroughout the day. No explanation was provided for how the injuries occurred. There wereno other children at the home at the time of the incident. The mother obtained a PFA againstthe father and relocated. narrative: 17. A 4-month-old male child nearly died on October 31, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Delaware County Children and Youth Agency indicated the case on December 29, 2017,naming the child’s father and mother as the perpetrators. On the date of the incident, thechild was transported to the hospital by the mother and father. The parents reported that thechild was lethargic. The child presented with seizure activity and was intubated and put on aventilator. The child had a computerized tomography scan on October 31, 2017, and a magnetic resonance imaging scan on November 2, 2017. It was determined that the childhad bilateral subdural brain hemorrhages, bleeding on both sides of the brain, and aligament injury in his neck. Medical professionals stated that the child’s injuries wereconsistent with non-accidental trauma. In addition, the child had petechia along the neck,chest, and arms, subdural hematomas, and an extensive brain injury. The parents were theonly caretakers for the victim child during the time when the incident would have occurred.There is one older sibling in the home. A safety plan was implemented and the parents are2017 4th Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesOctober 1 to December 30, 2017 8not to have any unsupervised contact with the children. narrative: 18. A 6-month-old male child nearly died on August 14, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Montgomery County Office of Children & Youth (MCOCY) indicated the case on October 17,2017, naming the biological father and mother as the perpetrators. The child was in the careof the maternal grandfather while the parents were working. The pediatrician recommended the child be taken to the local emergency room.The child was diagnosed with a skull fracture and an epidural hematoma. Itwas determined that the injury was a result of non-accidental trauma occurring within thepreceding 24 hours. The father was the primary caretaker of the child during that timeframe.The mother was named as a perpetrator by omission through her failure to act as she wasaware of an unexplained bump developing while in the sole care of the father. The maternalgrandfather was ruled out as a possible perpetrator. The child was released into the care ofan aunt. The child and maternal half-sibling living in the home at the time of the incident nowlive with the maternal grandfather as a part of the safety plan arrangement. The parents arereceiving case management services through MCOCY. They are cooperating and visitingthe child under supervision. A police investigation is pending. The family had no priordocumented involvement with child welfare.

narrative: 24. A 4-year-old male child nearly died on September 28, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case on October 26,2017, naming the child’s mother and her paramour as the perpetrators. The child’s body hadinjuries consistent with having been struck by both a linear object and/or belt. narrative: 27. A 22-month-old female child nearly died on September 1, 2017, as a result of seriousphysical neglect. Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case onOctober 20, 2017, naming the biological mother and father as the perpetrators. The victimchild’s primary care physician completed an examination on August 31, 2017 and sent thechild immediately to the local emergency room due to signs of failure to thrive. The child wasin the zero percentile of height and weight. The child had missed multiple previouslyscheduled medical appointments. Medical authorities diagnosed the child with severemalnutrition and her bones had not formed properly. Her limbs were visibly deformed, andshe was non-weight bearing. These conditions were somewhat attributed to a medicaldiagnosis of Rickets. PDHS concluded that both parents were responsible for the child’sfailure to thrive due to their negligence. There were two other children, a full sibling and ahalf sibling, residing in the home. The children appeared to be of appropriate weight and didnot appear to be malnourished or dehydrated. The full sibling was placed in the home of astep-grandmother as a part of a safety plan. The half sibling was placed with the paternalgrandmother along with the victim child. The parents have supervised visitation with thechildren. PDHS is providing services to the family including parenting capacity evaluations,dual diagnosis assessments, and random drug screens. There has not been action by lawenforcement in the case. The family had no prior documented child welfare involvement.

narrative: 31. A 12-year-old female child nearly died on August 29, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Philadelphia Department of Human Services indicated the case on October 18,2017, naming the child’s mother and mother’s paramour as the perpetrators. On August 29,2017, the child was brought to a local hospital by her mother and her mother’s paramourafter suffering two seizure episodes at home. The child was not immediately transported viaambulance after the first seizure episode. The child suffered another seizure episode at thehospital. The child required intubation and mechanical ventilator support and wassubsequently transferred to a specialized pediatric hospital. It was reported that the child’sfailure to thrive, her seizures, and her need for emergency medical intervention were due toinadequate caloric intake and water overload. The child weighed 56 pounds and had onlygained nine pounds in two years. There were concerns for child maltreatment as it wasreported that the child was often hungry but given water instead of food. The food was keptin a padlocked area that only the mother and her paramour could access. Both admitted tosupplementing the child’s meals with an excess of water. The mother reported makingmeals such as oatmeal, bread, and noodles to fill up the child and her 10-year-old brotherwho also lives in the home. The victim child’s brother was evaluated at the local pediatrichospital on August 31, 2017, and immediately admitted for concerns of severe malnutrition.On September 8, 2017, the children were discharged from the hospital and placed in fostercare. The children were referred for behavioral health services in addition to casemanagement services to coordinate their follow up medical care. On October 19, 2017, thechild’s mother and mother’s paramour were arrested and charged with aggravated assault,2017 4th Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesOctober 1 to December 30, 2017 13conspiracy, two counts of endangering the welfare of a child, simple assault, and recklesslyendangering another person. They were both incarcerated until December 4, 2017, whenthe judge dismissed the criminal charges due to a lack of evidence. The family had no priordocumented child welfare involvement.Westmoreland County

prior_status: The family had no prior documented child welfare involvement.
narrative: 33. A 5-year-old male child nearly died on September 14, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Wyoming County Children and Youth Services indicated the case on November 9, 2017,naming the child’s father as the perpetrator. On September 14, 2017, the father brought thevictim child and the child’s two siblings to a friend’s home. The father got into an altercationwith another adult and took out a pocketknife. The father reports holding the knife by hisside and the child running into the knife. The child was transported by emergency medicalservices (EMS) to the hospital. EMS was unable to obtain a blood pressure reading and thechild was in and out of consciousness. The child suffered a traumatic knife injury to the leftupper lobe of the heart, lacerating his subclavian artery resulting in hemorrhagic shock andcardiac arrest. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation was performed on the child. The child alsosuffered brain injury from the incident. The child’s injuries required extensive surgicalprocedures. The child stabilized and was transported by helicopter to a pediatric surgicalfacility. The extent of his injuries required additional surgery and therapies. The child was care his mother on November 2, 2017. The child will need extensive rehabilitation. Themother, child, and child’s sibling are not in need of child welfare services at this time. Thefather, his paramour, and their children were assessed and are receiving services. Theirchildren have been placed in kinship care. The mother filed a Protection from Abuse orderagainst the father. A three-year no contact order was granted. The father has beencriminally charged. He was charged with aggravated assault, aggravated assault-victim lessthan 13, simple assault, endangering welfare of children, simple assault, and recklesslyendangering another person. The family had no prior documented child welfare involvement.

A 3-year-old female child died on November 28, 2017, due to physical abuse.Columbia County Children and Youth Services indicated the case on January 24,2018, naming the mother’s paramour as the perpetrator. On November 25, 2017,the mother left the victim child in the care of her paramour while she was at work.The mother stated that the victim child appeared to be fine when she left. Laterthat morning, the mother’s paramour went to wake the victim child and found herunresponsive, so he put her in a cold bath. The child remained unresponsive. Themother’s paramour attempted cardiopulmonary resuscitation without success andthen contacted emergency medical services. The child was transported to a localhospital. The victim child presented at the local hospital with bruises on the left1September 4, 20182018 1st Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesJanuary 1 to March 31, 2018and right side of her head and the left lower rib cage. OnNovember 28, 2017, the victim child died. It was suspected that the mother’sparamour caused the injuries to the victim child. There were no other children inthe home at the time of the incident. After the victim child’s death, the mother’sparamour fled to Florida and a warrant for his arrest was issued. On December 15,2017, the mother’s paramour was arrested and brought back to Pennsylvania. Hewas charged with homicide and he is currently incarcerated awaiting trial. Thefamily had no prior documented Pennsylvania child welfare involvement. narrative: 5. An 11-month-old male child died on December 5, 2017, as a result of seriousphysical neglect. Erie County Office of Children, Youth and Families (ECOCYF)indicated the report on January 23, 2018, naming the father and the mother as2September 4, 20182018 1st Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesJanuary 1 to March 31, 2018the perpetrators. On December 5, 2017, the child was brought to the localhospital in critical condition. He was transferred via medical helicopter to aspecialized pediatric hospital where he was pronounced brain dead on December 8, 2017, and later died on December 9, 2017. The child had been left in the bathtub by his father while he left the residence to go cash a check. The mother hadjust returned home from work and the father had neglected to tell the mother hehad left the victim child in the bath tub when he left the residence. The mother didnot check on either of the children while the father was not in the residence andthe children were under her care. When the father returned 20 to 30 minuteslater, he found the child face down in the tub with the water still running. Thefather attempted cardiopulmonary resuscitation while someone else in the homecalled emergency medical services. As a result of the investigation, a case was opened. The mother delivered another child on January 5, 2018. This child wastaken into agency custody on January 8, 2018 and placed into foster care. Thatchild and three of the mother’s children were all found dependent on January 18,2018 and the three older children were subsequently removed from the mother’shome. ECOCYF is providing in-home services to the father of the older threechildren. Parenting services are being provided to the mother. The criminal case isstill ongoing and to date no charges have been filed. ECOCYF had prior historywith the family; three previous general protective service referrals being receivedbetween August 2015 and April 2017, due to the children being born exposed tomarijuana and concerns for lack of supervision. All reports were determined to bevalid. In August 2015 the parents declined services and the case was closed September 30, 2015. In December 2016, the case was closed at intake. In April2017, early intervention services were suggested however it was unknown if the family followed through and the case was closed in June 2017.Franklin

prior_status: The family has a history of involvement with PDHS beginning witha GPS report in 2001 for failure to provide medical care that was determined to be invalid.
narrative: 9. A 9-month-old female child died on September 23, 2017, as a result of physicalabuse. Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) substantiated the caseon February 2, 2018, naming the mother as the perpetrator. On December 11,2017, DHS received a child protective services (CPS) report and a general protectiveservices (GPS) report alleging the child’s postmortem toxicology tests were positivefor lethal levels of the narcotic Oxycodone. A GPS report was made immediatelyfollowing the victim child’s death in September, however, there were no suspicionsat that time that the victim child’s death had been a result of abuse or neglect.Following the receipt of the toxicology results the mother reported she was prescribed Oxycodone following automobile accidents in 2016 and 2017. Themother stated she stored the medication in the medicine cabinet in the bathroomand took the medication as needed. The only explanation provided by the motherfor the ingestion was that a pill could have possibly fallen on the floor and thevictim child, who was able to crawl, found it and swallowed it. At the time of thevictim child’s death, the four oldest of the remaining seven children in the familywere receiving services through a Community Umbrella Agency. Two of the fourchildren were in placement to address truancy and behavioral issues. Two otherswere receiving in-home safety services. The other children living in the home weredetermined to not have a need for services. PDHS created a plan to ensure thesafety of the children for the duration of the investigation. No criminal chargeshave been filed. The family has a history of involvement with PDHS beginning witha GPS report in 2001 for failure to provide medical care that was determined to be invalid. The family had further involvement with PDHS from 2014 to 2017. Duringthat time period a CPS report was received alleging physical abuse of one of thechildren in the family. The report was determined to be unfounded. Also, duringthat time period three GPS reports were received. One report involved concernswith a sibling’s behavior in school which was screened out. A second reportinvolving behavioral concerns of one of the children in the family was determinedto be valid. The last GPS report was related to the victim child and thecircumstances surrounding the child’s death. The report was determined to beinvalid. The family received case management services in the home from variousPDHS provider agencies from 2014-2017 to address concerns identified in thereports.

narrative: 10. A 4-day-old male child died on February 3, 2018, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Philadelphia Department of Human Services indicated the case on March27, 2018, naming the mother and father as perpetrators. On the day of theincident, the victim child’s father picked the victim child up for a feeding and5September 4, 20182018 1st Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesJanuary 1 to March 31, 2018noticed the victim child was having difficulty breathing. The father patted thevictim child on the back to clear out the airway. The victim child becameunresponsive and died in his father’s arms. The victim child was delivered by thefather who was assisted by the paternal grandmother. The victim child received nomedical attention before the incident. The family practices a religion that does notbelieve in medical care. The parents notified the Pastor of their church of the victimchild’s death and was advised by the Pastor to call a funeral home. The funeralhome personnel contacted the medical examiner who informed law enforcementand paramedics. Reports suggest the child had been deceased for an extendedperiod of time prior to emergency services response. It was determined that thechild died from an infection in the intestines which could have been treated byproper medical care. There were three siblings in the home other than the victimchild. The children’s ages were six, four and two years old. The County Childrenand Youth Agency found no safety threats upon assessment and allowed thechildren to remain in the home. The 6-year-old sibling’s medical care wasmonitored by a medical professional for an irregular heartbeat during home visits.Law enforcement continues the criminal investigation. The family had no priordocumented child welfare involvement.Near FatalitiesAllegheny

Allegheny County Children, Youth and Families (CYF) indicated thereport on January 17, 2018, naming the mother and father as the perpetrators.The victim child was brought to a local pediatric hospital on November 19, 2017,after the mother found blood in the victim child’s vomit after a feeding. The parents were unable to provide plausible explanationsabout how these injuries occurred and physicians determined that these injurieswere indicative of child abuse. The victim child was placed into kinship care upondischarge from the hospital. There were no other children in the household.Allegheny County CYF accepted the family for services, such as parenting classes,visit coaching, and substance abuse assessments. narrative: 14. An 11-year-old female child nearly died on January 26, 2018, as a result ofserious physical neglect. After lunch the brother found the victim childbreathing heavily. The father returned home and took the victim child to thehospital. The victim child presented at the local hospital in a diabetic coma andsubsequently was transferred to another hospital. The perpetrators admitted the medication wasadministered inconsistently. The agency implemented a safety plan upon the victimchild’s discharge. The victim child returned home under the stipulation that thevictim child would not be supervised by a minor child and would receive in-homenursing five times per week. There are two other children in the home, a sister age 13 and a brother age 16. Both children were assessed and determined to be safe inthe home. The case is currently under criminal investigation and no charges havebeen filed at this time. The family has been opened for services with NCCYFD. Theagency will continue to provide in-home nursing services and monitor compliancewith the victim child’s medical condition. The family had no prior documentedchild welfare involvementPhiladelphia

narrative: 21. A 9-year-old female child nearly died on January 19, 2018, as a result of seriousphysical neglect. Philadelphia County Department of Human Services (PDHS)indicated the report on January 19, 2018, naming the father and mother as theperpetrators. EMS responders arrived at the home andcontinued CPR and victim child was observed to have a pulse. The victim child wastransported to a local specialized pediatric hospital after suffering what wasdetermined to be a near fatal asthma attack. The victim child remained in the hospital for observation and treatment and was discharged on January 24, 2018.There was determined to be a failure of providing medical treatment/care to thevictim child. The parents were aware of the severity of the victim child’s medicalcondition and failed to take the victim child to seven medical appointments to see aspecialist. The mother had also stopped giving the victim child a prescribedmedication. The victim child has four siblings. An urgent petition was filed onJanuary 31, 2018, and the siblings were removed from the home and placed with akinship family. As the result of the investigation, the family is receiving functionalfamily therapy, domestic violence services, individual therapy, and random drugand alcohol screenings. The parents have supervised visitation at the discretion ofthe kinship parents. The family has prior history with PDHS. A general protectiveservices (GPS) report was received in October 2006 due to a 3-month-old siblingwho was found to be unresponsive, then pronounced dead upon arriving to thelocal hospital. The cause of death was undetermined, cerebral anoxia. In March2017, another GPS report was received and validated due to domestic violencebetween the parents. The family began receiving in-home safety services on March23, 2017 and were receiving them at the time of the incident.

narrative: 7. A 4-year-old female child died on October 18, 2017, as a result of physicalabuse. Montgomery County Office of Children and Youth (MCOCY) indicatedthe report on November 3, 2018, naming the victim child’s mother andmother’s paramour as the perpetrators. On the date of the incident, themother went to work and left the victim child in the care of the paramour. Theparamour attempted to wake the victim child, but she would not wake up. Theparamour then called the mother and the mother returned home and calledemergency medical services (EMS). Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) wasperformed on the victim child until EMS arrived. The victim child presented atthe hospital with blood on her mouth and shirt, bleeding in the eyes, andbruising to the abdomen. The victim child later succumbed to her injuries. Themedical examiner concluded that the cause of death was undeterminedbecause it could not be ruled out that the injuries were not caused by the CPRperformed. The MCOCY investigation into the incident was also unfounded.On September 18, 2018, the victim child’s 9-year-old sibling was brought tothe local children’s hospital emergency room. The sibling presented at thehospital with injuries similar to that of the deceased victim child. The siblingwas diagnosed with strangulation and restriction of the airways, and thesibling stated that he “did not want to die like” the sister. The sibling’shospitalization prompted the victim child’s case to be reinvestigated. Thehospital determined that the victim child had been strangled because that wasthe only justification for bleeding in the eyes. The hospital further determined3 July 19, 20242018 4th Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesOctober 1 to December 31, 2018that the victim child’s injuries were a result of child abuse sustained over aperiod of time and not a result of CPR performed. At the time the reportregarding the victim child was indicated, the hospital had requested that themedical examiner’s office review the findings with another pathologist andresults were still pending. It was determined that the mother’s paramourcaused the victim child’s injuries and the victim child’s mother failed toprotect her from abuse. The victim child’s two siblings were then placed in thecare of the maternal grandparents by court order. The victim child’s motherwas also residing in the home, and services were provided to the family. At thetime the report was indicated, the mother’s paramour had been arrested andcharged. The family had no prior documented child welfare involvement.Northumberland

narrative: 6. A 4-month-old male child nearly died on March 15, 2020 as a result ofphysical abuse. Cambria County Children and Youth Services indicated thereport on April 9, 2020, naming the victim child’s stepfather as theperpetrator. On the date of the incident, the stepfather reported that thevictim child had fallen off a mattress less than a foot off the ground and wasunresponsive. The mother was out of state at the time of the incident andhad left the child in the care of the stepfather. The child was transported tothe hospital via emergency medical services and upon examination the childwas filthy, lethargic, and not responding appropriately. It was determinedthe child had an acute subdural hematoma, two head bleeds at the midlineshift, and a petechia rash to the face. The injuries sustained by the childwere highly concerning for inflicted trauma and more specifically, abusivehead trauma. The stepfather was the only caretaker for the child at the timeof the incident. As the result of the safety assessment completed, upondischarge from the hospital, the child returned to the care of the mother andno services were provided. There were no other children in the home. At thetime the report was indicated, the criminal investigation was pending, andno criminal charges had been filed. The family had no prior documentedchild welfare involvement.

narrative: 11. A less than one-day-old male child nearly died on December 4, 2019 as aresult of physical abuse. Lehigh County Children and Youth indicated thereport on April 17, 2020, naming the victim child’s mother and father asthe perpetrators. On February 21, 2020, at two-months-old, the victimchild was taken to the doctor by the victim child’s mother and subsequentlysent to the local emergency where the child was admitted. The victim childpresented malnourished and was found to have multiple abrasions to thetorso, right and left side rib fractures, a clavicle fracture, a skull fracture asubdural hematoma, and healing fractures on the knee. The fractures onthe ribs were found to be in various stages of healing. Due to themultiplicity of injuries and the varying time frames relating to the healingrib fracture it was determined through the investigation that the injurieswere sustained from multiple incidents and over an extended time framedating back to December 4, 2019, when the child was less than one-dayold. The investigation also determined that both parents were responsiblefor the care of the child during the time period when the injuries weresustained. As the result of the safety assessment completed, the victimchild and one other child in home at the time of the incident were placedwith relatives and services were provided. At the time the report wasindicated, the criminal investigation was pending, and no criminal chargeshad been filed. The family had no prior documented child welfareinvolvement.McKean

narrative: 16. A 2-year-old male child nearly died on December 4, 2019 as a result ofserious physical neglect.
